clinical_study.brief_title: E-nose Utility in the Diagnosis of Bacterial Infection in COPD
clinical_study.official_title: E-nose Utility in the Diagnosis of Bacterial Infection in Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD)

lead_sponsor.agency: Fundació Institut de Recerca de l'Hospital de la Santa Creu i Sant Pau

clinical_study.source: Fundació Institut de Recerca de l'Hospital de la Santa Creu i Sant Pau

brief_summary.textblock: Hypothesis: A commercial e-nose (Cyranose 320) is able to detect specific breathprints from patients with COPD and bacterial infection

detailed_description.textblock: Thirty to 50% of COPD patients have airway colonization with potentially pathogenic bacteria. This is associated with worse prognosis. Currently, diagnosis of bacterial colonization relies mainly upon quantitative sputum culture. However, this method lacks good sensitivity. The electronic nose is a novel device made up of nanosensors capable of detecting specific volatile organic compounds (VOCs). OBJECTIVES: Main 1) To assess the usefulness of the electronic nose in the diagnosis of bacterial colonization in COPD. Secondary 1) To define the VOCs pattern associated with bacterial colonization. 2) To study the pattern of pulmonary and systemic inflammation associated with bacterial colonization as well its relationship with the aforementioned VOCs patterns.

primary_outcome.measure: Breathprint in exhaled breath from patients with COPD
primary_outcome.description: Breathprints will be assessed by discriminant analysis on principal component reduction, resulting in cross-validated accuracy values

secondary_outcome.measure: Breathprint in exhaled breath from COPD patients with bacterial colonization
secondary_outcome.description: Breathprints will be assessed by discriminant analysis on principal component reduction, resulting in cross-validated accuracy values
